text: to the young who could be the New York
Times this is Lydia poll Green the
Golden Temple in the northern punjab
region of india is the holiest shrine of
the sikh religion it is a vast complex
of marble and glittering gold there's a
refuge in a chaotic country with a
history of religious strife woodland
temple is a unique place in the world
which is having a very good concept the
concept of humanity now where is this
principle more evident than in the
temples community kitchen that kitchen
is based on the principle to suppress
the caste system in the society we are
human beings and we are equal that's why
everybody sit together eat together in
the kitchen it is perhaps the largest
free eatery in the world on a weekday 80
thousand people dine here on weekends
it's almost twice that
each visitor gets a vegetarian meal
served up by volunteers who come to find
a measure of peace not available
anywhere else I need the dough and I
roll it into balls no one feels that
they're forced to serve others the
atmosphere is very nice the system here
is very nice the kitchen managers here
are very humble all of us work together
Sikhism emerged in the Punjab region in
the 15th century it uses elements of
both Hinduism and Islam while rejecting
the Hindu notion of caste for Sikhs
everyone is considered equal in all
faiths are welcome at the temple after
you man Brahman I belong to a Brahmin
Hindu family I get lots of positive
vibes from this place I believe in this
place a lot and I get much peace of mind
when I'm here if we talk about feelings
then whoever comes here feels great they
get a peace of mind they get
satisfaction and whoever will come here
will take something along with them
